chapters.content:
Chapter 1 covers construction heaters including propane cylinder selection and connection. POL fittings are turned counterclockwise into cylinder threads and tightened with a wrench. The regulator should be positioned so the hose leaving it is horizontal, protecting the vent from weather. All connections must be checked for leaks using a leak detector or soap solution. The propane cylinder should always be kept upright to prevent liquid propane from flowing to the heater.

Radiant construction heaters use infrared heat which minimizes moisture buildup within the building under construction and helps to dry out materials and concrete. An infrared construction heater can radiate 250,000 Btu/h at 360 °F heat over a 5000 ft² area. Natural gas heater models are popular with construction rental companies as they combine benefits with consistent fuel supply. These heaters can be disconnected when construction is finalized and the furnace then connected to the meter supply. Gas utility companies have policies and procedures for connection, activation, and meter coordination.

Indirect-fired heaters are used for applications that call for clean air free from moisture and contaminated fumes. They are available as dual-fuel heaters operating on propane and natural gas. To change fuels, a selector valve must be turned to its proper position and the safety lock engaged. Units range from approximately 400,000 Btu/h to much larger skid-mounted units with millions of Btu/h capacity. Flexible ducting is used to bring warm air into the building and may also be used to return air to the heater. The vent outlet pipe requires a minimum of 2 ft vertical flue pipe. For indoor installations, the vent must terminate outdoors within the maximum length limitations specified by the manufacturer.

Maintenance is necessary to maintain reliable performance. Never service a heater while it is plugged in, connected to a gas supply, operating, or hot as this creates risk of severe burns and electrical shock. General maintenance steps include: keeping the heater clean with a damp cloth and household cleaners; inspecting the heater before each use; visually checking cords, connectors, wiring, conduit, heater shell, and control box; inspecting the hose/regulator assembly before each use; keeping the inside free from combustibles and foreign objects; and cleaning fan blades each season or as needed.

Extensive maintenance includes blowing the outside of the unit with compressed air to remove accumulated dust, blowing the entire burner face moving back and forth until all dust is dislodged from the grid screen, and blowing through the venturi starting from the control end. Clean the orifice, clean the thermocouple lead, and clean the flame rod and insulator with soap and water or solvent. Clean the spark plug with solvent and check the spark gap. Clean the inside of the control box with a dry cloth or compressed air (do not use any liquid or aerosol spray cleaners). Check the motor and oil (and add if required), check the tightness of the set screw on the fan motor, and run the heater to check for fan vibration.

assignment_questions.question: For a millivolt control system, which thermostat wire gauge enables the farthest distance between the thermostat and the heater?
assignment_questions.explanation: For millivolt control systems, 14 GA wire gauge enables the farthest distance between thermostat and heater due to lower resistance.

assignment_questions.question: Space heaters installed in a bathroom must be of the direct-vent type.
assignment_questions.explanation: Space heaters in bathrooms must be direct-vent type for safety and proper ventilation in enclosed, moisture-prone areas.

assignment_questions.question: A thermostat should be located approximately _______ distance from the floor.
assignment_questions.explanation: Thermostats should be located approximately 5 ft (150 cm) from the floor for proper ambient temperature sensing.

assignment_questions.question: A space heater should have a maintenance inspection _______.
assignment_questions.explanation: Space heaters require maintenance inspection at least annually to ensure reliable and safe operation.

assignment_questions.question: On a room heater, the draft relief opening is typically located _______.
options: On the side of the unit
At the lower front of the unit
Under the draft hood at the back of the unit
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Under the draft hood at the back of the unit
assignment_questions.explanation: The draft relief opening is typically located under the draft hood at the back of the unit to provide proper draft relief.

assignment_questions.question: What is the purpose of a reversible draft diverter on a gas room heater?
options: To connect the unit to a direct-vent kit
To enable the unit to be used as an unvented heater
To enable a horizontal-vent connection to the unit
assignment_questions.correct_answer: To enable a horizontal-vent connection to the unit
assignment_questions.explanation: A reversible draft diverter enables a horizontal-vent connection to the unit, providing installation flexibility.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ control valve provides an infinite number of firing rates between low fire and high fire.
assignment_questions.explanation: A modulating control valve provides an infinite number of firing rates between low fire and high fire for precise temperature control.

assignment_questions.question: A/An _______ heater unit produces a low-pressure, high-volume flow.
assignment_questions.explanation: A blower type heater unit produces a low-pressure, high-volume flow for efficient air circulation.

assignment_questions.question: A/An _______ wall furnace reduces heat stratification in a room.
assignment_questions.explanation: A counterflow type wall furnace reduces heat stratification by directing heated air downward and promoting better air mixing.

assignment_questions.question: A Type _______ vent is used in a conventional wall furnace.
assignment_questions.explanation: A Type BW vent is used in conventional wall furnaces, designed for wall-mounted venting applications.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ thermostat is required for a fully modulating unit heater.
assignment_questions.explanation: A modulating thermostat is required for a fully modulating unit heater to control the infinite firing rate adjustments.

assignment_questions.question: A wall furnace can be installed directly on a wooden floor.
assignment_questions.explanation: A wall furnace cannot be installed directly on a wooden floor due to clearance and safety requirements for combustible materials.

assignment_questions.question: The electrical supply for a baseboard heater may be plugged directly into a wall receptacle.
assignment_questions.explanation: The electrical supply for a baseboard heater must be hardwired and cannot be plugged into a wall receptacle due to load requirements and safety standards.

assignment_questions.question: Direct-vent wall furnaces are only available as natural convection units.
assignment_questions.explanation: Direct-vent wall furnaces are available as both natural convection and fan-assisted units.

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following components directs the heat from a low-intensity infrared heater onto the floor?
assignment_questions.explanation: A reflector directs the heat from a low-intensity infrared heater onto the floor, focusing the radiant heat downward.

assignment_questions.question: A temperature level of _______ may be reached with a high-intensity infrared heater.
assignment_questions.explanation: High-intensity infrared heaters can reach temperature levels of 1800 °F (980 °C) for maximum radiant heat output.

assignment_questions.question: All infrared heaters are vented.
assignment_questions.explanation: Not all infrared heaters are vented; some low-intensity models can be unvented depending on design and application.

assignment_questions.question: Clean the outside surfaces of the reflector with _______.
assignment_questions.explanation: Clean the outside surfaces of the reflector with a damp cloth to avoid damaging the reflective surface.

assignment_questions.question: The combustion products of a construction heater are vented into the heated area.
assignment_questions.explanation: For many construction heaters, combustion products are vented into the heated area. However, indirect-fired heaters vent combustion products separately to provide clean air.

assignment_questions.question: Which type of construction heater is used for applications that call for clean air that is free from moisture and contaminated fumes?
assignment_questions.explanation: Indirect-fired construction heaters are used for applications requiring clean air free from moisture and contaminated fumes, as combustion products are vented separately.

assignment_questions.question: Which component will stop the flow of gas when a heater is accidentally knocked over?
assignment_questions.explanation: A tip-over switch stops the flow of gas when a heater is accidentally knocked over, providing critical safety protection.

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers fireplaces and their components. Box burners are made of sheet metal that is slotted or punched to form ports and then bent into a box shape. The holes and slots can be arranged to create a specific flame pattern. After being bent into a box shape, the box seams are made gastight. Box burners have an air shutter attached or a separate venturi tube.

Ceramic-tile burners consist of a ceramic tile mounted in a sheet metal box. The ceramic tile has many small ports arranged in a very uniform pattern. The box holds the ceramic tile and provides a space into which the gas and primary air mixture flow. The ceramic tile is brittle and can crack. Bending or prying the ceramic burner can cause gas to leak around the ceramic tile which can change the flame appearance and make the appliance unsafe.

Pilot-burner assemblies are determined by the type of ignition/safety control system used. The two most common types are continuous pilot and intermittent pilot. In addition to igniting the main burner, a continuous or standing pilot also energizes the millivolt control system. An intermittent pilot is automatically ignited when the fireplace is called on to operate and extinguished when the main burner operating cycle is complete. Although a fireplace with continuous pilot ignition can increase energy costs, it has the advantage of operating as an auxiliary heat source that is not dependent on electricity. Modern fireplace electronic burner controls can operate on low DC voltage and can use common dry cell batteries as their backup or main power source, giving intermittent pilot models the same auxiliary heat benefit. Most provinces have adopted energy efficiency standards which ban the sale of continuous pilot fireplaces.

All gas fireplaces fall into one of two categories: decorative gas fireplaces or heating gas fireplaces. There are three common configurations: gas fireplace inserts, zero-clearance gas fireplaces, and free-standing gas fireplaces. Any of these three types may be available as decorative or heating appliances depending on their efficiency. The glass fronts can be manufactured from tempered or ceramic glass. Ceramic glass is slightly better at transmitting infrared heat and can withstand the higher temperatures that accompany sealed units. A fourth type of fireplace conversion occurs with a gas log set which is strictly classified as decorative.

The two categories are differentiated by their efficiency. Decorative gas fireplaces do not have a minimum efficiency requirement, while heating gas fireplaces must have a minimum FE of 50% as per CSA P.4.1. For new installations effective January 1, 2010, both categories must be capable of automatic extinguishment of the pilot flame when the main gas burner flame is established and extinguished, prevention of the pilot flame burning continuously for more than seven days if manually switchable to continuous pilot operation, and prevention of any ignition source for the main gas burner flame from operating continuously for more than seven days. New installations must also have a direct-vent configuration unless marked for replacement use only.

Gas log sets provide the effects of an open fire without wood, smoke, or ashes. A gas flame provided by a bar-type burner is placed under an arrangement of ceramic logs. Gas logs provide no real heat and can cause venting system problems if the wood fireplace chimney is not relined to accommodate lower-temperature flue gas. The gas log set must be installed only in a vented wood-burning fireplace constructed of non-combustible materials with a working flue. The fireplace damper must be locked fully open when gas logs are installed. A damper stop clam with set screw is provided to prevent the damper blade from closing. If a damper stop cannot be installed, substitute a permanent damper stop that keeps the damper open a minimum of 1.5 in (37 mm). Poor flue draft is normally indicated by fumes smelling like smouldering lamp oil. Gas logs should be operated with glass doors fully opened and screens opened enough to provide sufficient combustion air. The gas log set should be visually inspected and cleaned annually.

Fireplace inserts are used to convert existing wood-burning masonry or factory-built fireplaces to gas. Once converted, the fireplace can no longer be used to burn solid fuels. The gas burner and simulated logs are contained in a special metal housing (engine) that fits into the existing fireplace cavity. Some inserts are designed with part of the heat exchange surface extending into the heating space providing radiant heat. Do not insulate around the fireplace insert as this can result in overheating and possible malfunction of any circulating fan. If the insert is natural-draft type, it draws air from the front and outer perimeters providing combustion air, dilution air for venting, and air heated over the heat exchanger. Since most new homes are tightly sealed, direct-vent units are preferred as they have a dedicated combustion air supply duct from outside.

Zero-clearance gas fireplaces are used in installations where there is no existing fireplace. These units are usually installed during construction of new homes or during renovation. They have flexibility in location and can be built into a wall, corner, peninsula, or island. Installation involves building the space and framing for the unit. Approved venting materials must be used and manufacturer instructions must be followed for proper clearances from combustibles. The glass used is special high-temperature ceramic glass. If damaged, it should be replaced with a complete glass and frame assembly purchased from an authorized dealer. Substituting with lower-grade glass can cause injury or property damage. The glass should be cleaned with a fireplace glass cleaner to avoid damaging the surface.

Control systems include continuous pilot systems and electronic ignition systems. Continuous pilot systems are not dependent on electricity as the control circuit is powered by a thermopile. The continuous pilot also energizes the thermocouple and flame safety circuit. Intermittent pilot circuits require a power source to operate. They ignite automatically when a fireplace is called on to operate and extinguish when the main burner operating cycle is complete. The flame safety circuit can be a conventional thermocouple connected directly to a gas valve or an electronic flame rod system communicating with a control module. A simple main burner control circuit includes the source of power, a gas valve, and a manual on-off switch or thermostat.

Some models are supplied with an on-off switch or integral thermostat. Other models are designed to be connected to an external thermostat. Modern fireplaces come with remote-control thermostat options. A remote-control thermostat has two components: a transmitter (handset) and a receiver. The hand-held control enables temperature control and on-off operation. Both units have a battery power supply that needs to be replaced every six months. The receiver is attached to the fireplace and synched to the transmitter enabling communication between the components. Electronic ignition systems operate on 24 V ac supplied from a step-down transformer and rely upon a 120 V ac power supply to operate.

Some units are equipped with a vent safety shutdown switch that is factory installed, wired, and tested. Some gas fireplaces have an optional temperature-sensitive switch that turns the blower on and off thermostatically. The blower comes on automatically when the fireplace reaches its optimum operating temperature and turns off automatically when the unit shuts down and temperature decreases.

Many fireplace manufacturers offer blowers installed at factory or as aftermarket options. The blower is thermally activated and starts automatically approximately 10 min after lighting the fireplace and runs for approximately 30 to 45 min after the fireplace has been turned off. Using the fan increases the heat distribution output. The fireplace installation requires a 120 V power source to accommodate the blower. Maintenance includes cleaning the blower assembly and replacing the motor and bearings as necessary.

Some models of zero-clearance fireplaces have knockouts on the exterior for connection of air ducts to disperse warm air to remote locations. These duct systems must be specifically approved for the particular gas fireplace. The air duct kit has its own fan assembly, and the internal fireplace blower cannot be operated when the air duct kit is in use.

Modern fireplace electronic burner controls can operate on low DC voltage allowing them to use common dry cell batteries as a backup or main power source. All components in the control circuit come from the same manufacturer and are designed to work with each other on 6 V dc. Modern controls can include options to modulate flame height and heat output as part of the temperature control system. The receiver/control module has a compartment to install 4 AA batteries or a separate battery holder. Fireplace control manufacturers are also creating apps to enable owners to use their personal devices to control their gas fireplace.

Assembly procedures include installing the circulating blower kit if supplied separately and ensuring there is a 120 V ac power supply outlet. Carefully follow placement instructions for the log or ceramic stone as not doing so can lead to blocked burner ports causing incorrect flame pattern, carbon deposits, and delayed ignition. Check that the relief door fibreglass seals are intact, inspect the glass door gasket and install the glass door as per instructions, and install the wire mesh safety barrier designed to reduce the risk of burns from hot viewing glass.

Before leaving the unit, ensure the appliance is firing correctly and fully explain to the owner the unit's startup, shutdown, and operation procedures. When operating the fireplace for the first time, some vapours may be released when curing compounds are burnt. It is possible for these vapours to set off a smoke-detection alarm. Open a window to vent the room. After a few hours, the vapours will disappear. Do not place clothing or flammable materials on or near the appliance. Do not place furniture or any other combustible household objects within 36 in of the front of the fireplace. Free-standing fireplaces can be a greater burn hazard and young children should be carefully supervised. Inform the owner of the location of the external vent cap and tell them to ensure no debris, plants, trees, or shrubs interfere with the airflow.

Maintenance includes recommending that the homeowner hire a qualified service technician to perform appliance check-ups at the beginning of each heating season. Inspect and operate the pressure relief mechanism to ensure it is free from obstruction and the seals are intact. Use a recommended fireplace glass cleaner to clean both sides of the glass after the first 10 h of operation and thereafter clean as required. Failure to keep the glass clean may result in permanent discoloration or blemishes. Inspect the operation of the flame safety system pilot or flame rectification device. Ensure that lighting of the main burner occurs quickly and smoothly. Visual inspection should match the guidelines outlined in the appliance instruction manual. Inspect primary air openings for blockages. Inspect the condition of the vent and vent terminal for sooting or obstruction and correct if present. Check for evidence of excessive condensation such as water droplets forming in the inner liner and dripping out of the joints. Vacuum and clean debris out of the firebox. Test and measure the flame failure response time of the flame safety system. Check all accessible gas-carrying tubes, connections, pipes, and other components for leaks. Replace the batteries in the handset and receiver.

assignment_questions.question: Which two categories of gas fireplace are identified in Canada's Energy Efficiency Regulations?
options: Gas fireplace inserts and gas stoves
Zero-clearance gas fireplaces and gas logs
Decorative gas fireplaces and heating gas fireplaces
Vent-free gas fireplace and decorative appliances
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Decorative gas fireplaces and heating gas fireplaces
assignment_questions.explanation: Canada's Energy Efficiency Regulations identify two categories: decorative gas fireplaces (no minimum efficiency) and heating gas fireplaces (minimum 50% FE).

assignment_questions.question: Which type of gas fireplace is used to convert an existing wood-burning masonry chimney to gas?
assignment_questions.explanation: Fireplace inserts are used to convert existing wood-burning masonry or factory-built fireplaces to gas. Once converted, they can no longer burn solid fuels.

assignment_questions.question: A/An _______ type of gas fireplace is used on a new home installation and is surrounded by framing.
assignment_questions.explanation: Zero-clearance gas fireplaces are used where there is no existing fireplace, installed during new home construction or renovation, and surrounded by framing.

assignment_questions.question: What is the minimum FE rating for heating gas fireplaces?
assignment_questions.explanation: Heating gas fireplaces must have a minimum FE (fireplace efficiency) of 50% as per CSA P.4.1.

assignment_questions.question: When installing a gas log set into a vented wood-burning fireplace, the damper must be _______.
options: Locked in a fully open position
Locked in a fully closed position
assignment_questions.correct_answer: Locked in a fully open position
assignment_questions.explanation: When installing gas logs, the fireplace damper must be locked fully open using a damper stop clam with set screw or permanent damper stop.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ type of direct vent uses completely separate pipes.
assignment_questions.explanation: A collinear type of direct vent uses completely separate pipes for combustion air intake and exhaust venting.

assignment_questions.question: Which type of glass is used on a gas fireplace?
assignment_questions.explanation: Ceramic glass is used on gas fireplaces as it is high-temperature resistant and slightly better at transmitting infrared heat into the room.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ controls the blower in a gas fireplace.
assignment_questions.explanation: A temperature-sensitive switch controls the blower in a gas fireplace, turning it on and off thermostatically based on operating temperature.

assignment_questions.question: What purpose does a standing pilot have (in addition to lighting the main burner)?
options: To energize the millivolt control circuit
To complete the flame-rod sensing circuit
To heat the bulb of the thermostatic switch
assignment_questions.correct_answer: To energize the millivolt control circuit
assignment_questions.explanation: In addition to igniting the main burner, a standing (continuous) pilot energizes the millivolt control system and the thermocouple flame safety circuit.

assignment_questions.question: A _______ type of venting system enables units to be installed with longer horizontal vent runs.
assignment_questions.explanation: A power venting system uses a fan to enable units to be installed with longer horizontal vent runs and more flexible installation locations.

assignment_questions.question: Air duct kits may be installed onto any gas fireplace.
assignment_questions.explanation: Air duct kits cannot be installed onto any gas fireplace. They must be specifically approved for the particular gas fireplace model.

assignment_questions.question: Modern intermittent pilot fireplaces control circuits operate on which voltage?
assignment_questions.explanation: Modern intermittent pilot fireplace control circuits operate on 6 V dc, allowing them to use common dry cell batteries (4 AA batteries) as backup or main power source.

documents.content:
CSA Unit 21 - Space Heaters and Fireplaces Test (100 Questions)
Questions 1-25: General Requirements and Space Heater Types
What is the definition of a room heater? a) A ducted heating system that provides warm air throughout a building b) A self-contained, free-standing, non-recessed, gas-burning appliance that furnishes direct warm air to the space in which it is installed without ducting c) A wall-mounted heating unit that requires electrical power d) A temporary heating solution used only in construction
What does "flash back" refer to in gas heating terminology? a) A safety feature that prevents overheating b) A loud ignition noise followed by a hissing sound c) The automatic restart of a heating system d) A type of flame pattern
According to CSA B149.1, what should prevail if there is a discrepancy between manufacturer's instructions and codes? a) The manufacturer's instructions b) Local building codes c) The most stringent requirements d) Provincial regulations only
What is spalling in relation to chimney flue liners? a) The installation of new liner materials b) When pieces of the chimney flue liner flake off or delaminate due to corrosive chemicals and moisture c) The cleaning process for flue systems d) A type of venting material
What is the purpose of a tip-over switch? a) To control the flame height b) To stop the flow of gas when the heater is accidentally knocked over c) To regulate air flow d) To monitor combustion efficiency
For unvented space heaters, what is the general rule for residential buildings in most provinces of Canada? a) They are allowed with proper ventilation b) They require special permits c) It is not permissible to install them in residential buildings d) They can only be used in basements
What type of venting system do direct-vent space heaters use? a) Room air for combustion with indoor exhaust b) Combustion air from outside with flue products exhausted outdoors c) Natural draft only d) No venting required
When installing a heating appliance on carpet or vinyl tile, what protection is required? a) No special protection needed b) A metal or wood panel extending the full width and depth of the appliance c) Only fireproof carpet padding d) Elevation of at least 12 inches
In a residential garage, how high above the floor must a heater be located? a) 12 inches (305 mm) b) 18 inches (396 mm) c) 24 inches (610 mm) d) 36 inches (914 mm)
What type of space heater is required for bathroom installation? a) Unvented type b) Natural draft type c) Direct-vent type d) Any certified type
Where should an external thermostat be positioned for space heaters? a) On an outside wall facing north b) On an inside wall in the same room as the heater, about 5 ft above the floor c) In an adjacent room for better control d) Near a window for natural light
For millivolt thermostats, what wire size allows for 100 ft (30 m) distance between thermostat and heater? a) 16 GA b) 18 GA c) 14 GA d) 20 GA
How often should space heaters be inspected? a) Monthly during heating season b) Before use and at least annually c) Only when problems occur d) Every five years
What should be used to check for gas leaks during maintenance? a) A match or lighter b) Electronic sensors only c) A leak detector or soap solution d) Visual inspection only
What type of sealant should be applied where igniter and thermocouple wires enter the combustion chamber? a) Standard silicone sealant b) High-temperature silicone sealant c) Plumber's putty d) No sealant required
What are the three main types of room heaters based on venting? a) Electric, gas, and oil b) Gravity vented, fan-type vented, and unvented c) Indoor, outdoor, and portable d) High-efficiency, standard, and basic
In what fan switch position does the fan come on automatically once the heater reaches a certain temperature? a) MAN position b) AUTO position c) OFF position d) HIGH position
What device must unvented gas-heating equipment include? a) A carbon monoxide detector b) An oxygen depletion sensor that shuts off the heater if oxygen becomes inadequate c) An automatic timer d) A humidity sensor
Where are unvented room heaters prohibited from installation? a) Residential homes only b) Commercial buildings c) Hotels, motels, or rooms of institutions such as hospitals or nursing homes d) Basement areas
What can you use to verify proper draft in room heaters? a) An electronic gauge b) A smoking match held near the draft diverter opening c) A pressure meter d) Visual inspection of flames
What is the input range for wall furnaces? a) 5,000 to 50,000 Btu/h b) 10,000 to 90,000 Btu/h c) 15,000 to 75,000 Btu/h d) 20,000 to 100,000 Btu/h
What type of vent is designed to fit inside a 2 × 4 stud wall? a) B vent b) BW vent c) C vent d) DW vent
How many baseboard heaters can be controlled from a single thermostat? a) Two b) Four c) Up to three, if all heaters are in the same room d) As many as needed
What is the anticipator setting for three baseboard heaters controlled by a single thermostat? a) 0.35 b) 0.7 c) 1.05 d) 1.4
What is the main advantage of infrared heaters? a) They heat air very efficiently b) They transfer heat directly to people and objects rather than heating the air c) They use less fuel than other heaters d) They operate silently
Questions 26-50: Unit Heaters and Installation Requirements
What are the two main types of fans used in gas unit heaters? a) Radial and centrifugal b) Axial and blower type (centrifugal) c) High-speed and low-speed d) Single-stage and two-stage
What efficiency do non-condensing power vented units achieve? a) Approximately 78% b) Approximately 84% c) Approximately 90% d) Approximately 95%
Why should copper not be used for condensate drains? a) It's too expensive b) It corrodes too quickly in normal conditions c) The water condensed from combustion products will be acidic d) It doesn't fit standard connections
What safety device protects unit heaters in case of motor failure or airflow restriction? a) Pressure switch b) Temperature-activated auto reset limit control c) Manual reset button d) Thermal fuse
What is the purpose of a high limit control in unit heaters? a) To control maximum temperature output b) To provide protection in case of motor failure or lack of airflow c) To regulate gas pressure d) To monitor combustion efficiency
What is the minimum upward slope required for horizontal vent runs? a) 1/8 inch per foot b) 1/4 inch per foot, or 1 in 50 c) 1/2 inch per foot d) 1 inch per foot
When may a vent restrictor be required in fireplace installations? a) In all installations b) When horizontal runs exceed 10 feet c) In installations with vertical rise d) Only in cold climates
How many sheet metal screws should be used to fasten a 4 inch inner vent joint? a) Two b) Three c) Four d) Six
What type of glass is used in gas fireplaces? a) Standard window glass b) Tempered glass c) Special, high-temperature, ceramic glass d) Plexiglass
What should be done with the fireplace damper when gas logs are installed? a) Leave it adjustable b) Close it completely c) Lock it fully open d) Remove it entirely
What is the minimum efficiency requirement for heating gas fireplaces under CAN/CSA P.4.1? a) 40% b) 50% c) 60% d) 70%
What happens to decorative gas fireplaces regarding efficiency requirements? a) They must meet 40% efficiency b) They must meet the same standards as heating fireplaces c) They do not have a minimum efficiency requirement d) They must meet 30% efficiency
As of January 1, 2010, what requirement applies to new gas fireplace installations? a) They must be direct-vent only b) They must have pilot flame control mechanisms c) They must include remote controls d) They must have electronic ignition
What is the main limitation of gas log sets? a) They are difficult to install b) They require special venting c) They provide no real heat to the house and can cause venting problems d) They are too expensive to operate
What must be done to logs before handling them during maintenance? a) Wear protective gloves b) Clean them first c) Do not handle logs until they have cooled d) Disconnect the gas supply
What type of combustion air supply do direct-vent fireplace inserts have? a) Room air only b) A dedicated combustion air supply duct from outside c) Mixed indoor and outdoor air d) Filtered indoor air
What is required for installation in R-2000 homes? a) Natural draft fireplaces only b) Power vented fireplaces c) Direct-vented (sealed) gas fireplaces d) Unvented fireplaces
In coaxial direct venting, what does the outer pipe do? a) Exhausts combustion products b) Brings combustion air in from outdoors c) Provides structural support d) Insulates the inner pipe
What safety feature must be included with power vent fan kits? a) Manual override switch b) Backup fan motor c) Interlock with fireplace controls to ensure fireplace cannot light unless power vent is functioning d) Emergency shut-off valve
Under what conditions should venting components from different manufacturers be combined? a) When they have the same dimensions b) When approved by local codes c) Different manufacturers' components must not be combined d) When using adapters
What powers the control circuit in continuous pilot systems? a) Household electricity b) Batteries c) The thermocouple and continuous pilot d) Solar power
How often should batteries in remote control systems be replaced? a) Every three months b) Every six months c) Annually d) Only when they fail
What voltage do modern electronic burner controls typically operate on? a) 120 VAC b) 24 VAC c) 12 VDC d) 6 VDC
How long after lighting should the thermally activated blower start? a) Immediately b) Approximately 5 minutes c) Approximately 10 minutes d) Approximately 15 minutes
How long does the blower typically run after the fireplace is turned off? a) 15-20 minutes b) 30-45 minutes c) 60-90 minutes d) Until manually shut off
Questions 51-75: Infrared Heaters and Construction Heaters
What is the minimum height requirement for

documents.content:
CSA Unit 21 - Space Heaters 
and Fireplaces                            
Chapter 1
Gas technicians and fitters need to be thoroughly familiar with the 
capabilities and uses of space heaters to ensure customer satisfaction. 
This presentation covers the general requirements, types, installation 
considerations, and maintenance procedures for various space heaters 
including room heaters, wall furnaces, baseboard heaters, infrared 
heaters, and construction heaters.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Objectives
List General Requirements
Understand the general requirements and code 
compliance for space heaters
Describe Room Heaters
Identify types, components, and maintenance 
procedures for room heaters
Describe Wall Furnaces
Understand the installation and operation of wall 
furnaces
Describe Baseboard Heaters
Learn about direct-vent baseboard heaters and their 
wiring
Describe Infrared Heaters
Understand the principles and applications of infrared 
heating
Describe Construction Heaters
Learn about temporary heating solutions for 
construction sites
Terminology
Term
Definition
Flash back
A loud ignition noise followed by a hissing 
sound
Heat anticipator
An electrical resistor device on many 
mechanical thermostats that fine tunes the 
point at which the thermostat turns off the 
furnace burners
Room heater
A self-contained, free-standing, non-
recessed, gas-burning appliance that 
furnishes direct warm air to the space in 
which it is installed without ducting
Space heater
See room heater
Spalling (in chimney flue liner)
When due to corrosive chemicals and 
moisture from combustion, pieces of the 
chimney flue liner flake off or delaminate
Tip-over switch
A switch that stops the flow of gas when the 
heater is accidentally knocked over
CSA Gas Trade Training 
Materials
Red Seal Alignment
The space heater training 
materials align with Red Seal 
Block tasks including safety-
related functions, maintenance 
of tools and equipment, and 
installation planning.
CSA Gas Trade Unit
Space Heaters and Decorative 
Appliances are covered in Unit 
23 of the CSA Gas Trade 
training materials.
Related Units
Other related units include Venting Practices, Forced Warm-air 
Heating Systems, and Controls: Fundamentals.
General Requirements for Space 
Heaters
Read Product Specifications
Before installation or service, read all product specifications and instructions to 
ensure maximum benefits and safety.
Check Certification
For safety reasons, verify that the space heater is certified by CSA Group or 
another certifying agency.
Follow Code Requirements
Install according to CSA B149.1, national and provincial building codes, and 
electrical codes.
Proper Sizing
Ensure the appliance can provide the expected heat requirements for the space.
Code Requirements
Follow CSA B149.1
Space heaters must be installed according to the national gas code
Comply with Building Codes
National and provincial building codes must be followed
Meet Electrical Codes
All electrical connections must comply with electrical codes
Apply Most Stringent Requirements
If there is a discrepancy between manufacturer's instructions and codes, the most stringent requirements shall prevail
Appliance Selection and Sizing
Check Rating Plate
Before installing the heating unit, check the rating plate for 
the rated output and ensure that the appliance can provide 
the expected heat requirements.
For example, the customer may have purchased the heating 
unit expecting it to heat a very large room, but its rating is 
only enough to heat a small room.
Avoid Oversizing
If it is a large-input heater, check that the room is big 
enough so that the unit will operate efficiently. If the unit is 
too large, it will operate for only short periods of time before 
being shut off by the thermostat.
The ASHRAE Handbook — HVAC Systems and Equipment 
has produced a heater sizing guide that summarizes studies 
on the use of gas-fired, in-space supplemental heaters in 
test houses.
Heater Sizing Guide

AFUE

Gas input required for in-space supplemental heaters (Btu/h per cu ft house volume)
Venting Classification
Unvented
Unvented space heaters are 
designed so that the room within 
which the appliance is installed 
both provides the combustion air 
and has the flue products 
exhausted into it.
It is not permissible to install 
unvented space heaters in 
residential buildings in most 
provinces of Canada.
Direct-vent
Direct-vent space heaters have 
combustion air supplied directly 
from the outside and the flue 
products are also exhausted to the 
outdoors. The exhaust vent and 
combustion air inlet are often 
combined in one unit.
Vented
Vented appliances take the combustion air from the room and exhaust the 
products of combustion to the outdoors.
Venting Requirements
Follow Manufacturer's Instructions
Installation instructions provide specific information on venting 
materials and installation parameters
Wall Thickness
Maximum and minimum wall thickness allowed for direct-vent 
appliances
Vent Material
B, BW, single wall within heated space; special venting for outdoor use
Starter Vent Kit
Manufacturers often provide a starter vent kit with the appliance 
including vent, spacers, collars, terminals, etc.
Masonry Chimney Requirements
Do
•
Inspect the masonry chimney before installing the unit
•
Make sure that the chimney's clay flue liner is not 
cracked, soft, or spalled
•
Verify that mortar joints between liner sections are in 
place and tight
•
Clean creosote from the top, sides, and back of a 
masonry firebox before installing a non-vented 
decorative appliance
•
Check whether your local codes require the fireplace 
damper to be clamped open or removed
Do Not
•
Share a gas-fired appliance flue with a wood-burning 
appliance
Proper vent termination for any gas-fired appliance is 
critical to the overall safe and efficient functioning of the 
venting system. The vent terminal clearance criteria for 
space heaters follows standard practice as outlined in Unit 
22 Venting Practices.
General Installation Considerations
1
Location
Due to high temperatures, the appliance should be located out of traffic and away from 
furniture and draperies.
2
Clear Area
The appliance area must remain clear and free from combustible materials, gasoline, 
and other flammable vapours and liquids.
3
Glass Integrity
If the appliance has glass, it should not be operated with the glass removed, cracked, or 
broken. Replacement of the glass should be done by a licensed or qualified service 
person.
4
Floor Protection
If installing the heating appliance on carpet, vinyl tile, or any combustible material, it 
must be first installed on a metal or wood panel extending the full width and depth of the 
appliance.
Installation in Special Locations
Garage Installation
If installed in a residential garage, 
the heater must be protected from 
damage and must be located no 
less than 18 inches (396 mm) above 
the floor.
Sleeping Room Installation
A room heater may be installed in a 
sleeping room provided that it is of 
the automatic temperature control 
type, is equipped with a pressure 
regulator, has a 100% safety shut-
off, and is vented.
Bathroom Installation
Space heaters installed in a 
bathroom must be of the direct-
vent type.
Combustion Air Requirements
Air Supply
Because many space heaters receive their combustion air 
from the room, it is very important that the air supply inlets 
at the front or side of the appliance remain free from 
obstruction.
Room heaters should not be used in a room that has limited 
air exchange with adjacent spaces, since combustion air is 
required for the space.
Customer Instructions
Typically, the manufacturer's instructions provide cautions 
concerning any potential dangers:
•
Children and adults should be alerted to the hazards of 
high surface temperature and stay away to avoid burns 
or clothing ignition
•
Young children need careful supervision when in the 
same room as the heating unit
•
Clothing and other flammable material should not be 
placed on or near the heating unit
Thermostat Installation
Position on Inside Wall
Install external thermostat on an inside wall in the same room as the 
heater
Proper Height
Position about 5 ft (150 cm) above the floor
Easy Access
Ensure position provides ready access to wiring, temperature 
adjustment, and servicing
Avoid Problem Areas
Do not locate in unusually warm/cold areas, direct sunlight, near 
heat sources, or areas with poor air circulation
Millivolt Thermostats
Special Requirements
The requirements for locating millivolt thermostats are 
somewhat different because the power supply is self-
generated, and the system can therefore power only a 
limited number of components.
Since the thermostat wire in the system adds resistance — 
resulting in a voltage drop - the size of the wire is 
proportional to the distance between the thermostat and 
the appliance. For example, a larger gauge of wire has less 
resistance, therefore the thermostat can be located further 
from the appliance.
Size of copper wire (solid 
or stranded)
Distance between 
thermostat and heater
14 GA
100 ft (30 m)
16 GA
64 ft (19.2 m)

40 ft (12 m)

25 ft (7.5 m)
22 GA
16 ft (4.8 m)
Programmable Thermostats
Compatibility with 
Millivolt Systems
Some electronic 
programmable thermostats 
are compatible with millivolt 
systems since many now 
utilize a battery backup power 
supply.
No Transformer 
Required
Many modern programmable 
thermostats do not require a 
24-volt transformer to power 
the thermostat.
Verification Required
Always confirm the thermostat compatibility prior to installation.
General Maintenance 
Considerations
Regular Cleaning
Space heaters require regular cleaning, both i

documents.content:
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 21 – Chapter 01: Space heaters 
 
1. For a millivolt control system, select the thermostat wire gauge that will enable the farthest 
distance between the thermostat and the heater? 
a) 14 GA 
b) 16 GA 
c) 18 GA 
d) 20 GA 
 
2. Space heaters installed in a bathroom must be of the direct-vent type. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
3. At approximately what distance from the floor should a thermostat be located? 
a) 100 cm 
b) 125 cm 
c) 150 cm 
d) 200cm 
 
4. How often should a space heater have a maintenance inspection? 
a) Minimum monthly 
b) Minimum annually 
c) Minimum every 5 years 
d) Never these unit are maintenance free 
 
5. Where is the draft relief opening typically located on a room heater? 
a) On top of the unit 
b) On the side of the unit 
c) At the lower front of the unit 
d) Under the draft hood at the back of the unit
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
2 
6. What is the purpose of a reversible draft diverter on a gas room heater? 
a) To connect a power vent 
b) To connect unit to a direct vent kit 
c) Enable unit to be used as an unvented heater 
d) To enable a horizontal vent connection to the unit 
 
7. Which type of control valve will provide an infinite number of firing rates between low fire 
and high fire? 
a) Manual control valve 
b) Two stage control valve 
c) Modulating control valve 
d) Single-stage control valve 
 
8. What type of unit heater produces low pressure, high volume flow? 
a) Blower type 
b) Axial fan type 
c) Counterflow type 
d) Low intensity type 
 
9. Which type of wall furnace will reduce heat stratification in a room? 
a) Blower type 
b) Axial fan type 
c) Counterflow type 
d) Low intensity type 
 
10. Which type of vent is used in a conventional wall furnace? 
a) B vent 
b) C vent 
c) BH vent 
d) BW vent
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
3 
11. What type of thermostat is required for a fully modulating unit heater? 
a) Millivolt thermostat  
b) Two stage thermostat 
c) Modulating thermostat 
d) Single stage thermostat 
 
12. A wall furnace can be installed directly on a wood floor. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
13. A baseboard heater’s electrical supply may be plugged directly into a wall receptacle. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
14. Direct vent wall furnaces are only available as natural convection units. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
15. There are 3 heaters, each with a 0.25 amp control circuit all being control by one 
thermostat. What should the amperage setting be for a thermostat with an anticipator? 
a) 0.25 amps 
b) 0.50 amps 
c) 0.75 amps 
d) amps 
 
16. What component directs the heat from a low-intensity infrared heater onto the floor? 
a) Fan 
b) Reflector 
c) Ceramic mat 
d) Radiant tube
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
4 
17. What temperature level may be reached with a high-intensity infrared heater? 
a) 6500C 
b) 9800C 
c) 12000C 
d) 18000C 
 
18. All infrared heaters are vented. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
19. How are the outside surfaces of the reflector cleaned? 
a) Steel wool 
b) Damp cloth 
c) Wire brush 
d) Power washer 
 
20. The combustion products of a construction heater are vented into the heated area. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
21. What type of construction heater would be used for applications that call for clean air, free 
from moisture and contaminated fumes? 
a) Blower 
b) Radiant 
c) Natural gas 
d) Indirect fired 
 
22. What component is designed to stop the flow of gas when the heater is accidentally knocked 
over? 
a) Piezo switch 
b) Off-level switch 
c) Tip-over switch 
d) High-limit switch

documents.content:
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
1 
Unit 21 – Chapter 02: Fireplaces 
 
1. What are the two categories of gas fireplaces identified by the Canadian Energy Efficiency 
Regulation? 
a) Gas fireplace inserts and gas stoves 
b) Zero-clearance gas fireplaces and gas logs  
c) Decorative gas fireplaces and heating gas fireplaces 
d) Vent free gas fireplace and decorative appliances 
 
2. What type of gas fireplace is used to convert an existing wood burning masonry chimney to 
gas? 
a) Insert 
b) Power vented 
c) Free-standing 
d) Zero-clearance 
 
3. What type of gas fireplace is used on a new home installation and surrounded by framing? 
a) Insert 
b) Power vented 
c) Free-standing 
d) Zero-clearance 
 
4. What is the minimum FE rating for heating gas fireplaces? 
a) 50% 
b) 75% 
c) 90% 
d) There is no minimum efficiency requirement
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
2 
5. What must be done with the damper when installing a gas log set into a vented wood 
burning fireplace? 
a) Throttled as needed 
b) Locked in fully open position 
c) Locked in fully closed position 
d) Operating handle modified for accessibility 
 
6. What type of direct vent uses to completely separate pipes? 
a) Coaxial 
b) Collinear 
c) Power 
d) Natural 
 
7. What type of glass is used on a gas fireplace? 
a) Tinted 
b) Ceramic 
c) Annealed 
d) Laminated 
 
8. How is the blower controlled in a gas fireplace? 
a) Thermopile 
b) Pressure switch 
c) Wall thermostat 
d) Temperature sensitive switch 
 
9. Besides lighting the main burner, what purpose does a standing pilot have?  
a) Preheats the chimney flue 
b) Energizes the millivolt control circuit 
c) Completes the flame rod sensing circuit 
d) Heats the bulb of the thermostatic switch
Gas Trade Training – Chapter Questions 
Updated: November 2019 
 
 
© 2019 Canadian Standards Association  
 
3 
10. What type of venting system enables units to be installed with longer horizontal vent runs? 
a) Coaxial 
b) Collinear 
c) Power 
d) Natural 
 
11. Air Duct kits may be installed onto any gas fireplace. 
a) True 
b) False 
 
12. Modern intermittent pilot fireplaces control circuits operate on what voltage? 
a) 6 VDC 
b) 24 VAC 
c) 120VAC 
d) 750 millivolts

Using the reference table and valve layout below, conduct each of the following measurements to the appropriate terminals and verify your readings.
Have the thermostat contacts open and pilostat knob turned to the off position. Coil resistance should be around 2.25 ohms. If not, replace the valve.
The system resistance from the remote switch or thermostat and lead wires should not exceed 1.7 ohms. If greater, reduce the resistance by reducing the thermostat run length, use a larger gauge wire, or replace the thermostat.
With the pilostat knob turned to “Pilot” and the thermostat open, push down the pilot valve button and ignite the pilot flame with the piezo ignitor. There should be a minimum of 325 mV. If not, inspect the position of the thermopile in the flame and the cleanliness of thermopile. If both are adequate, replace the thermopile.
With the pilostat knob left in the “Pilot” position and pilot still burning, close the thermostat contacts. The thermopile should provide at least 100 mV. If not, replace the thermopile. If the input is at least 100 mV, the valve operator will make an audible click inside the valve when it engages. If the valve does not make a sound, replace it.
If you are unsure how to make the readings, ASK! Indicate your readings below: (4 marks)

For complete information, see installation instructions packed with your dryer.
DUCTING MATERIALS: For best performance, this dryer should be vented 
with 4" diameter all rigid metal exhaust duct. If rigid metal duct cannot be 
used, then UL-listed flexible metal (semi-rigid) ducting can be used (Kit 
WX08X10077). In special installations, it may be necessary to connect the dryer 
to the house vent using a flexible metal (foil-type) duct. A UL-listed flexible 
metal (foil-type) duct may be used ONLY in installations where rigid metal or 
flexible metal (semi-rigid)  ducting cannot be used AND where a 4" diameter 
can be maintained throughout the entire length of the transition duct. Please 
see installation instruction packed with your dryer for complete instructions 
when using flexible metal (foil type) ducting.
EXHAUST LENGTH CALCULATION:
1. Determine the number of 90° turns needed for your installation. If you 
exhaust to the side or bottom of dryer, add one turn.
2. The maximum length of 4" rigid (aluminum or galvanized) duct which can be 
tolerated is shown  in the table.
For every extra 90° elbow, reduce the allowable vent system length by 10 ft. Two 
45° elbows will be treated like one 90° elbow. For the side exhaust installations, 
add one 90° elbow to the chart. The total vent system length includes all the 
straight portions and elbows of the system (transition duct included).
Dryers must be exhausted to the outside.
CAUTION: For personal safety do not terminate exhaust into a chimney, under 
any enclosed house floor (crawl space), or into an attic, since the accumulated 
lint could create a fire hazard or moisture could cause damage. Never terminate 
the exhaust into a common duct or plenum with a kitchen exhaust, since the 
combination of lint and grease could create a fire hazard.
Exhaust ducts should be terminated in a dampered wall cap to prevent back 
drafts, bird nesting, etc. The wall cap must also be located at least 12" above the 
ground or any other obstruction with the opening pointed down.

• Appliance installation must be performed by a qualified

• Install the appliance according to these instructions 
and local codes.
• DO NOT install a clothes dryer with flexible plastic venting 
materials. If flexible metal (semi-rigid or foil-type) duct is 
installed, it must be UL-listed and installed in accordance 
with the instructions found in “Connecting the Dryer 
to House Vent” later in this manual. Flexible venting 
materials are known to collapse, be easily crushed and 
trap lint. These conditions will obstruct dryer airflow and 
increase the risk of fire.
• DO NOT install or store this appliance in any location 
where it could be exposed to water or weather.
• To reduce the risk of severe injury or death, follow all 
installation instructions.
• Save these instructions. (Installers: Be sure to leave 
these instructions with the customer.)

• Installation must be performed by a qualified or

or licensed by the State.

exceed 3 feet.

This product contains one or more chemicals known to the State of California to cause cancer, and birth

formaldehyde and soot, caused primarily by the incomplete combustion of natural gas or LP fuels. Exposure to these

• The dryer MUST be vented to the outdoors.
• The exhaust vent MUST be securely fastened to a 
non-combustible portion of the mobile home.
• The vent MUST NOT be terminated beneath a 
mobile or manufactured home.
• The vent duct material MUST BE METAL.
• KIT 14-D346-33 MUST be used to attach the dryer 
securely to the structure.
• The vent MUST NOT be connected to any other 
duct, vent or chimney.
• DO NOT use sheet metal screws or other 
fastening devices which extend into the interior of 
the exhaust vent.
• Provide an opening with a free area of at least 25 
square inches for introduction of outside air into 
the dryer room.
• See the sections for electrical connection information.
REQUIREMENTS FOR ALCOVE OR 
CLOSET INSTALLATION
Keep flammable materials and vapors, such as 
gasoline, away from dryer.
Failure to do so can result in death, explosion, or fire.
• The dryer MUST be vented to the outdoors. 
• Minimum clearance between dryer cabinet and 
adjacent walls or other surfaces is:
 0” either side

• Consideration must be given to provide adequate

• Closet doors must be louvered or otherwise ventilated 
and doors must contain a minimum of:
  72 square inches of open area for GUD24 series 
models
  120 square inches of open area for GUD27 and

the same closet as a gas dryer.
• The dryer must be disconnected from the gas 
supply piping during pressure testing at pressures 
greater than ½ psi (3.5 kPa).
• A 1/8 inch NPT minimum plugged tapping, 
accessible for test gauge connection, must be 
installed immediately upstream of the gas supply 
connection to the dryer.
MINIMUM CLEARANCE OTHER THAN

Minimum clearance to combustible surfaces and 
for air opening are: 0” both sides, 0” rear and 1” top. 
Consideration must be given to provide adequate 
clearance for installation and service.

LOCATION
This appliance must be installed on firm flooring to minimize 
vibration during spin cycle. Concrete flooring is best, but 
wood base is sufficient, provided floor support meets FHA 
standards. This appliance should not be installed on rugs.

1.  In an area exposed to dripping water or outside 
weather conditions. The ambient temperature should 
never be below 60°F (15.6°C) for proper operation.
2.  In an area where it will come in contact with curtains 
or drapes.

• A 1/8” National Pipe Taper thread plugged

local gas utility should you have questions on the

the same room with, the dryer.
• Use pipe thread compound appropriate for

• Connect flexible metal connector to dryer and

ADJUSTING FOR ELEVATION
• Gas clothes dryers input ratings are based on 
sea level operation and need not be adjusted 
for operation at or below 2000 ft. elevation. For

-	 Leave the building immediately.
-	 Immediately call your gas supplier from 
a neighbor’s phone. Follow the gas sup-
plier’s instructions.
-	 If you cannot reach your gas supplier, call 
the fire department.

Installation/Owner’s Manual
Installation and Appliance Setup
INSTALLER:  Leave this manual with party responsible for use and operation.
OWNER:  Retain this manual for future reference.
-	 DO NOT store or use gasoline or other flammable 
vapors and liquids in the vicinity of this or any other 
appliance.
-	 What to do if you smell gas	 	
•	 DO NOT try to light any appliance.
•	 DO NOT touch any electrical switch; do not use any 
phone in your building.
•	 Immediately call your gas supplier from a neighbor’s 
phone. Follow the gas supplier’s instructions.
•	 If you cannot reach your gas supplier, call the fire 
department.
-	 Installation and service must be performed by a qualified 
installer, service agency, or the gas supplier.
WARNING: If the information in these 
instructions is not followed exactly, a fire or 
explosion may result causing property damage, 
personal injury, or death.
HOT GLASS WILL CAUSE 
BURNS.
DO NOT TOUCH GLASS 
UNTIL  COOLED.
NEVER  ALLOW CHILDREN 
TO TOUCH GLASS.
A barrier designed to reduce the risk of burns 
from the hot viewing glass is provided with this 
appliance and shall be installed for the protection 
of children and other at-risk individuals.
! DANGER
Models:
CK-30
ADP-CK30
The CK-30 Cabinet Kit must be used with 
the ADP-CK30 adapter kit, INFIT-30-BK

EXCURSION-II

TRILLIANT30IN
NOTICE: SAVE THESE INSTRUCTIONS
This appliance may be installed as an OEM installation 
in manufactured home (USA only) or mobile home and 
must be installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s 
instructions and the manufactured home construction 
and safety standard, Title 24 CFR, Part 3280 or Standard 
for Instllation in Mobile Homes, CAN/CSA Z240MH, in 
Canada.
This appliance is only for use with the type(s) of gas 
indicated on the rating plate.
The surface of the appliance is hot when it is in use. 
Young children should be watched carefully when they 
are in the same room when the appliance is in use, and 
they should be taught to avoid the hot surface.  Keep 
any objects that can burn well away from the appliance, 
and observe the recommended clearances that follow.

2 Getting Started	
A.	 Design and Installation Considerations
This appliance may only terminate vertically, horizontal 
termination is not allowed. Hearth & Home Technologies 
direct vent gas appliances are designed to operate with all 
combustion air siphoned from outside of the building and 
all exhaust gases expelled to the outside. No additional 
outside air source is required.
Installation MUST comply with local, regional, state and 
national codes and regulations. Consult insurance carrier, 
local building inspector, fire officials or authorities having 
jurisdiction over restrictions, installation inspection and 
permits.
Before installing, determine the following:
•	 Where the appliance is to be installed.
•	 The vent system configuration to be used.
•	 Gas supply piping requirements.
•	 Electrical wiring requirements.
•	 Whether optional accessories—devices such as a fan  or 
remote control—are desired.
C.	 Inspect Appliance and Components
•	 Carefully remove the appliance and components from the 
packaging. 
•	 The vent system components and optional accessories 
may be shipped in separate packages. 
•	 If packaged separately, the log set must be installed. 
•	 Report to your dealer any parts damaged in shipment, 
particularly the condition of the glass. 
•	 Read all of the instructions before starting the 
installation. Follow these instructions carefully during 
the installation to ensure maximum safety and benefit.
WARNING! Risk of Fire or Explosion! Damaged parts 
could impair safe operation. DO NOT install damaged, 
incomplete or substitute components. Keep appliance dry.
B.	 Tools and Supplies Needed
Before beginning the installation be sure that the following 
tools and building supplies are available.
Tape measure	
Framing material
Pliers	
Hammer	
Phillips screwdriver	 Manometer
Gloves	
Framing square
Voltmeter	
Electric drill and bits (1/4 in.)
Plumb line	
Safety glasses
Level	
Reciprocating saw
Flat blade screwdriver
Non-corrosive leak check solution
1/2 - 3/4 in. length, #6 or #8 Self-drilling screws
Caulking material (300ºF minimum continuous exposure 
rating)
One 1/4 in. female connection (for optional fan).
WARNING! Risk of Fire, Explosion or Electric Shock! DO 
NOT use this appliance if any part has been under water. 
Call a qualified service technician to inspect the appliance 
and to replace any part of the control system and/or gas 
control which has been under water.

Rinnai Tankless Water Heater Installation and Operation Manual 
      WARNING 
If the information in these instructions is not followed exactly, a fire or explosion may result 
causing property damage, personal injury, or death. 
•	 Do not store or use gasoline or other flammable vapors and liquids in the vicinity of this or any 
other appliance. 
•	 WHAT TO DO IF YOU SMELL GAS
	
– Do not try to light any appliance. 
	
– Do not touch any electrical switch; do not use any phone in your building. 
	
– Immediately call your gas supplier from a neighbor’s phone. Follow the gas supplier’s 
instructions. 
	
– If you cannot reach your gas supplier, call the fire department. 
•	 Installation and service must be performed by a trained and qualified professional, service 
agency or the gas supplier. 
Assurez-vous de bien suivre les instructions données dans cette notice pour réduire au 
minimum le risque d’incendie ou d’explosion ou pour éviter tout dommage matériel, toute 
blessure ou la mort.
•	 Ne pas entreposer ni utiliser d’essence ou ni d’autres vapeurs ou liquides inflammables à 
proximité de cet appareil ou de tout autre appareil.
•	 QUE FAIRE SI VOUS SENTEZ UNE ODEUR DE GAZ :
	
– Ne pas tenter d’allumer d’appareil.
	
– Ne touchez à aucun interrupteur ; ne pas vous servir des téléphones se trouvant dans le 
bâtiment.
	
– Appelez immédiatement votre fournisseur de gaz depuis un voisin. Suivez les instructions 
du fournisseur.
	
– Si vous ne pouvez rejoindre le fournisseur, appelez le service des incendies.
•	 L’installation et l’entretien doivent être assurés par un installateur ou un service d’entretien 
qualifié ou par le fournisseur de gaz.
